properties.media:imagetext:
Sydney, Dec., 19, 1963
Dear F and P.
We had quite a typical French departure from Noumea.
The TAI large bus called
for us at Les Bungalows promptly at 2:30 in the afternoon and then made other stops
on the road into town. The French and Australians piling on at each stop with
bundles, babies, baskets and blankets in a welter of confusion.
Eventually we
arrived at the TAI city office where there ensued a long unexplained delay.
in official announced in rapid fire French and then in halting English that the air-
plane was having mechanical trouble and we would wait there to see whether or not
we'd fly. After an hour more all the French began scrambling back on the bus and
someone said " We're Going".
The drive to the airport, 30 miles, was magnificent.
When we got there all was confusion compounded. There must have been 300 people in
and around the small station with baggage scattered all over the place. It reminded
me of the time Bondy and I left Nanking for Hankow during the war.
We took an over
crowded lighter out to the steamer in mid river.
You cannot possibly conceive of
such confusion.
Each coolie trying to out screech the others.
Bondy reassured one
American inexperienced traveler who had 17 different pieces of baggage that out of
that bedlam would come order and he'd find all 17 pieces in his stateroom.
seemed like a thousand to one shot but that is just what happened to our friend and
also to ud. So it was with the French in Tantouta airport at Noumea.
it all straightened out, we got on the airplane, a Douglas DC & Jet, and we had a, /
very comfortable flight to Sydney.
However, I am glad to be away from the French.
The PAA #1 in Australia, Rush Clark, met us at the airport, whisked us through
customs, and drove us into the new Nenzirs Hotel, after going by his office to pick
up our mail.
Debby and I had a late snack and read our mail, a real treat.
day, Wed. the 18th, I had lunch at the American Club with Rush Clark and Debby
lunched with his wife.
Then that evening we all had drinks at Sir Hudson and Lady
Fysh's apartment after which they gave us a super dinner at a restaurant on Rose Bay
where the old flying boats used to base. Hudson Fysh is an old World War I pilot
who was born in Tasmania and came back here after the war to start Quantas which has
grown to be one of the largest airlines in the world. He and I served together on
the Executive Committee of IATA. He is plenty sharp- as evidence - we used to agree
on almost ever later a are F for Calmes en route Taursday Island, Of
course everything here is backwards - as we go north it gets hotter and we plan to
travel light leaving our suit cases here at the hotel.
We go out on the Great
Barrier Reef from Cairnes to Green Island for Sat. and Sunday the 21st and 22nd.
Then on the 23rd we fly from Cairnes to Thursday.
Dec. 23rd. It didn't work out that way.
When we arrived at Cairnes it seemed
best to make some changes in our plans. It would have been fun to have our Chrietmas
on Thursday Island but on the other hand we did not want to become a burden to
â€¢Dabby's friend Reg Soott.
So we phoned him on the day after our arrival here (Dec.21)
and cleared a program to fly up there on the 26th arriving about 4:30 in the after-
noon and come back here on the 27th. Meanwhile we learned two things. One,Green
Island wassfull up for the holidays and couldn't take us, and two, that is is a park
where it is against the law to do any shelling. So we stayed in the Great Northern
at Cairnes.
Sunday the 22nd we took a boat - with about 100 other passengers - out the 17
miles to Green Island on the Great BarrieR. Reef.
It is a beautiful coral island
of some 30 acres entirely surrounded by coral reefs. We took a glass bottomed boat
trip. Looked at the world famous under water museum and enjoyed ourselves - but no
shelling. Then today we got a drive U.R. self Holden (General Motors) and drove on
the wrong side of the road 50 miles up the coast to the small town of Port Douglas
where a shell merchant by the name of Tom Scullett has quite a collection. He had
bean recommended by a collector on Piji. Debby bought quite a few shells and
established a good contact for future acquisitions. While she was talking shells I
roamed aound town (which didn't take long) and talied to some old timers in front
of a "Pub". They told me that at one time there were 17 Pubs on the main street
where now there was only this one.
In their minds it was clear that civic importance
was measured in terms of the number of pubs. All this talk about pubs reminds me of
